title: Seismology Terms Quiz
description: Shake up your vocabulary with the science of earthquakes, from seismic waves and fault lines to measuring techniques and tectonic forces.

questions.question: What is the 'epicenter' of an earthquake?
options: The deepest point underground where an earthquake starts
The center of a tectonic plate
The point on the Earth's surface directly above where an earthquake originates
The farthest point that shaking is felt

questions.question: What is a 'seismograph'?
options: An instrument that detects and records the intensity and duration of ground movements

questions.question: What does the 'Richter scale' measure?
options: The magnitude or energy released by an earthquake

questions.question: What is a 'fault' in geology?
options: A fracture in the Earth's crust along which blocks of rock have moved

questions.question: What are 'aftershocks'?
options: Smaller earthquakes that follow the main earthquake in the same area
Cracks in buildings after an earthquake

questions.question: What is the 'hypocenter' (or focus) of an earthquake?
options: The edge of a tectonic plate
The center of a city hit by an earthquake
The surface location of greatest damage
The point underground where the rupture of rock first occurs

questions.question: What is 'liquefaction'?
options: The melting of rock into magma
When saturated soil loses strength during an earthquake and behaves like a liquid

questions.question: What are 'P-waves'?
options: Primary seismic waves that are the fastest and first to arrive, compressing and expanding rock
Waves that travel only through water

questions.question: What are 'S-waves'?
options: Secondary seismic waves that move rock side to side and cannot travel through liquids

questions.question: What is a 'tectonic plate'?
options: A large slab of Earth's lithosphere that moves, floats, and sometimes fractures
The inner core of the Earth

questions.question: What does 'subduction' describe?
options: The cracking of the Earth's surface
The process where one tectonic plate slides beneath another

questions.question: What is 'magnitude' in earthquake measurement?
options: A numerical value representing the energy released by an earthquake

questions.question: What is a 'foreshock'?
options: A smaller earthquake that precedes a larger earthquake in the same location
An aftershock that is stronger than the main quake

questions.question: What does the 'Modified Mercalli Intensity Scale' measure?
options: The observed effects and damage caused by an earthquake at specific locations
